Award.AwardTitle: Low Mass Galaxies and the Baryonic Tully Fisher Relation as a Distance Indicator
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is difficult to understand an astronomical object unless its distance is known. That is why distance estimators are so precious. Scaling relations can be used to infer the distance to a galaxy. The Baryonic Tully Fisher Relation (BTFR) links the spin speed of a galaxy to its total mass in gas and stars. Astronomers are just beginning to ask if low mass galaxies obey the BTFR. These galaxies are sprinkled throughout the local universe and knowing their distances can open novel lines of inquiry. The team will use observations from NSF's Arecibo Observatory to measure the gas content, spin speed and recession speed of low mass galaxies. They will tally up the total masses in baryons to see if the galaxies obey the BTFR. If so, they will derive distances to galaxies near and inside the Pisces-Perseus Supercluster (PPS). They will compare the new distances and recession speeds to simulations to understand how the PSS formed. Senior team members will train junior team members. The Cornell team will continue to participate in the Undergraduate ALFALFA Team initiative, thereby involving students at 19 primarily undergraduate institutions in the research.

The team will investigate the population of low-mass, HI-rich galaxies. Their goals are to (1) establish a robust BTFR for local star-forming disk galaxies, (2) use the BTFR as a distance estimator and to probe regimes where baryon deficiency becomes important, and (3) infer BTFR distances in the Pisces-Perseus Supercluster (PPS) and its foreground and background voids, to constrain simulations of PPS formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cosmological principle postulates that on large scales the universe is homogenous and isotropic. The smooth distribution of matter leads to the expectation of the simple expansion of the universe that is reflected in Hubble's Law: more distant galaxies are moving away from us faster than nearer ones in a linear way, so that the distance to a galaxy is given directly by its recessional velocity. In reality, however, the universe on smaller scales is far from homogeneous, with filamentary superclusters linking groups and clusters and surrounding nearly empty voids. This structured distribution of mass imprints complexity onto the expansion velocities, with galaxies near regions of higher density pulled towards them by their stronger gravitational fields. In comparison with the expectations of smooth Hubble flow, the perturbed velocity field can be used to trace the distribution of the total mass contained not only in the galaxies we see but also in the invisible "dark" matter.

This research program centers on an observational program designed to provide a measurement of the total mass along one of the most massive large-scale structures in the nearby Universe, the Pisces-Perseus Supercluster. This filamentary supercluster is relatively nearby and ideally situated nearly perpendicular to the line of sight and isolated from foreground and background structures by deep voids. Galaxies in its vicinity feel the attractive gravitational force of its mass and thus are expected to exhibit infall motions towards it. These infall motions show up as excess velocities over what is expected according to their distances from the smooth Hubble flow expansion of the universe. The supercluster's mass distribution can be traced by mapping these excess "peculiar" velocities. The measurement of peculiar velocities is made by the application of the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation (BTFR), an empirical scaling law that links the total baryonic mass contained in both stars and gas to the rotational velocity.  For disk galaxies, the BTFR offers a way to measure the distance to a galaxy independent of its recessional velocity. The difference between the observed recessional velocity and  that expected for a galaxy at that distance yields the peculiar velocity.

Understanding the physical basis of the BTFR and how it can be applied as a cosmological tool is complicated by observational and theoretical uncertainties and likely environmental effects. Much of our effort has focused on deriving a robust template BTFR so that peculiar motions can be measured. The team has used original observations from NSF's Arecibo telescope to measure the gas content, observed rotational velocity and recessional velocity of low mass galaxies in and near the Pisces-Perseus filament. Public optical and infrared survey databases have been used to calculate stellar masses that in combination with the radio spectra are used to tally up the total masses in baryons. We have developed an automatic spectral line fitting algorithm that uses the full information contained in the radio hydrogen line global profile to derive our measurements of the disk rotational velocity with full accounting for uncertainties. We have tested methods of fitting available datasets selected to probe different populations and volumes of the Local Universe with particular attention to understanding the impacts of sample selection and to identifying instances of unusual subsets of galaxies that are true outliers, including gas-rich ultra-diffuse galaxies and extremely low mass dwarfs. With our best-fit template BTFR, we make estimates of the mass of the supercluster by comparing the derived peculiar velocity field to those found around filaments identified in public numerical simulations. Datasets and analysis tools have been developed and made public along with publications presenting them in detail.

Faculty and undergraduate student members of the Undergraduate ALFALFA Team have been involved in all aspects of this research. Team members have contributed to observations made with Arecibo and NSF's Green Bank Telescope, data reduction, software and database development, catalog cross-matching, analysis pipeline development, comparison with numerical simulations, science analysis and preparing publications. A six-week summer program of daily lectures covering scientific topics, observing techniques, journal discussions, career development and hands-on activities was organized and presented. Cornell graduate students have participated in team activities and have served as subgroup leads and undergraduate mentors. Cornell undergraduates have undertaken individualized research and independent study projects, participated in collaborative activities and presented their results at team meetings and professional conferences.
